overview: The ACL is one of the most commonly injured ligaments of the knee. Approximately half of ACL injuries occur along with damage to the meniscus, articular cartilage, or other ligaments. Injured ligaments are considered sprains and are graded on a severity scale.
procedure_description: ACL tears are not usually repaired using sutures (stitches) because repaired ACLs have generally been shown to fail over time. The torn ACL is generally replaced by a substitute graft made of tendon, including patellar, hamstring, or quadriceps tendon autograft, or allograft.
recovery_time: 6 to 12 months
rehabilitation: Physical therapy is a crucial part of successful ACL surgery, with exercises beginning immediately after the surgery. Much of the success of ACL reconstructive surgery depends on the patient's dedication to rigorous physical therapy.
success_rate: High success rate with proper rehabilitation and adherence to post-operative care.
when_to_consider_surgery: Active adult patients involved in sports or jobs that require pivoting, turning, or hard-cutting should consider surgical treatment. Young children or adolescents with ACL tears should discuss the risks and benefits of surgery with their surgeon.
results: Most patients are allowed to return to full sports participation within 6 to 12 months, depending on the patient's progress, strength, and mechanics.
cost_estimation: Cost can vary widely based on location, surgeon, and facility, but it typically ranges from $5,000 to $20,000.

surgery_name: Anesthesia for Hip and Knee Surgery
overview: Anesthesia is a major decision that could have a major impact on your recovery. It deserves careful consideration and discussion with your surgeon and your anesthesiologist.
procedure_description: Anesthesia is used to manage pain during surgery and can be categorized into local, regional, and general anesthesia.

overview: Spinal fusion is a surgical procedure used to correct problems with the small bones in the spine (vertebrae). It is essentially a welding process. The basic idea is to fuse together the painful or unstable vertebrae so that they heal into a single, solid bone.
procedure_description: An interbody fusion is a type of spinal fusion that involves removing the intervertebral disk. When the disk space has been cleared out, your surgeon will implant a metal, plastic, or bone spacer between the two adjoining vertebrae. This spacer, or cage, promotes bone healing, helps make the fusion happen, and increases the collapsed intervertebral disk space.
risks_and_complications: Nerve damage, which can result in weakness in tapping your foot
Rare incidence of bowel, bladder, or blood vessel injury (<0.1%)
Incisional hernia (where the muscle seems to pouch out)
recovery_time: 1 to 3 days in the hospital after surgery, with most patients encouraged to stand and walk by the first day after surgery.
rehabilitation: Basic exercises, including routine walking, during the first several weeks after surgery. Avoid bending with your back, twisting, or lifting anything heavier than a gallon of milk.
results: Most patients who undergo ALIF can expect improvement of lower back pain and disability in weeks to months after surgery.

overview: Arthroscopy is a surgical procedure that orthopaedic surgeons use to visualize and treat problems inside a joint.
symptoms: Chondromalacia (wearing or injury of the cartilage cushion in the knee)
Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears with instability in the knee
Carpal tunnel syndrome in the wrist
Loose bodies of bone and/or cartilage
surgical_procedures: Repair or resection of torn cartilage (meniscus) from the knee or shoulder
Reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in the knee
Removal of the synovium in the knee, shoulder, elbow, wrist, or ankle
Release of the carpal tunnel in the wrist
Removal of loose bone or cartilage in the knee, shoulder, elbow, wrist, or ankle
procedure_description: In arthroscopic surgery, an orthopaedic surgeon makes a small incision in the patient's skin, then inserts pencil-sized instruments that contain a small lens and lighting system to magnify and illuminate the structures inside the joint. Light is transmitted through fiber optics to the end of the arthroscope that is inserted into the joint.
risks_and_complications: Damage to blood vessels or nerves
recovery_time: Several weeks for the joint to maximally recover; many patients return to daily activities within a few days.
rehabilitation: A specific activity and rehabilitation program may be suggested to speed recovery and protect future joint function.
when_to_consider_surgery: When conservative treatments fail or when a diagnosis requires surgical intervention.
results: Most patients have their arthroscopic surgery as outpatients and are home several hours after the surgery.

overview: Articular cartilage is the smooth, white tissue that covers the ends of bones where they come together to form joints. Healthy cartilage in our joints makes it easier to move. It allows the bones to glide over each other with very little friction. Articular cartilage can be damaged by injury or normal wear and tear. Because cartilage does not heal itself well, doctors have developed surgical techniques to stimulate the growth of new cartilage. Restoring articular cartilage can relieve pain and allow better function. Most important, it can delay or prevent the onset of arthritis.
procedure_description: Many procedures to restore articular cartilage are done arthroscopically. During arthroscopy, your surgeon makes two or three small, puncture incisions around your joint using an arthroscope. Some procedures require the surgeon to have more direct access to the affected area. Longer, open incisions are required. Sometimes it is necessary to address other problems in the joint, such as meniscal or ligament tears, when cartilage surgery is done. In general, recovery from an arthroscopic procedure is quicker and less painful than a traditional, open surgery. Your doctor will discuss the options with you to determine what kind of procedure is right for you.
recovery_time: Several months
rehabilitation: Physical therapy may be prescribed to restore mobility and strengthen the joint and supporting muscles.
success_rate: Varies by procedure and patient condition
when_to_consider_surgery: When cartilage damage is significant and causing pain or functional limitations, especially in younger patients with single lesions.
results: Can relieve pain and improve joint function, potentially delaying or preventing arthritis.

surgery_name: Artificial Disk Replacement in the Lumbar Spine
overview: In lumbar artificial disk replacement, worn or damaged disk material between the small bones in the spine (vertebrae) is removed and replaced with a prosthetic, or artificial disk. The goal of the procedure is to relieve back pain while maintaining more normal motion than is allowed with some other procedures, such as spinal fusion (which aims to prevent motion).
causes: Low back pain caused by one or two problematic (arthritic) intervertebral disks in the lumbar spine
symptoms: Pain that does not improve with conservative treatment
procedure_description: Most artificial disk replacement surgeries take 2 to 3 hours. Your surgical team will approach your lower back from the front through an incision in your abdomen. During the procedure, your surgeon will remove your problematic disk, then insert an artificial disk implant into the disk space.
recovery_time: 1 to 3 days in the hospital, with early motion encouraged
rehabilitation: Basic exercises, including routine walking and stretching, during the first several weeks after surgery.
success_rate: Success for lumbar fusion for low back pain due to a degenerative disk ranges from 50 to 90%. Disk replacement improves, but does not completely eliminate pain.
when_to_consider_surgery: When low back pain does not improve with conservative treatment and is caused by degenerative disks as determined by diagnostic testing and physical exam.
results: Most patients can expect improvement of lower back pain and disability in weeks to months after surgery.
cost_estimation: Insurance coverage for lumbar disk replacement varies; many insurance companies do not currently approve lumbar disk replacements.

overview: Awake spinal surgery, also known as intravenous sedation surgery, is a procedure where the patient remains awake during the operation. It can reduce the risks associated with general anesthesia, potentially leading to quicker recovery times and improved results for patients.
procedure_description: In awake spinal surgery, doctors use spinal anesthesia, which numbs the surgical area without putting the patient to sleep. This method is considered safer as it does not require a breathing tube.
risks_and_complications: Not everyone can have this kind of surgery
Anxiety or fear during the procedure
recovery_time: Patients will start moving around with help immediately after the procedure and will be evaluated for recovery from spinal anesthesia before discharge.

Rare incidence of bowel, bladder, or blood vessel injury (<0.1%)
Incisional hernia (where the muscle seems to pouch out)
recovery_time: 1 to 3 days in the hospital after surgery, with most patients encouraged to stand and walk by the first day after surgery.
rehabilitation: Basic exercises, including routine walking, during the first several weeks after surgery. Avoid bending with your back, twisting, or lifting anything heavier than a gallon of milk.
results: Most patients who undergo ALIF can expect improvement of lower back pain and disability in weeks to months after surgery.

overview: Arthroscopy is a surgical procedure that orthopaedic surgeons use to visualize and treat problems inside a joint.
symptoms: Chondromalacia (wearing or injury of the cartilage cushion in the knee)

Carpal tunnel syndrome in the wrist
Loose bodies of bone and/or cartilage

Reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in the knee
Removal of the synovium in the knee, shoulder, elbow, wrist, or ankle
Release of the carpal tunnel in the wrist
Removal of loose bone or cartilage in the knee, shoulder, elbow, wrist, or ankle

risks_and_complications: Damage to blood vessels or nerves
recovery_time: Several weeks for the joint to maximally recover; specific activity and rehabilitation program may be suggested to speed recovery.
rehabilitation: A specific activity and rehabilitation program may be suggested to speed your recovery and protect future joint function.
when_to_consider_surgery: When conservative treatments have failed or when the condition is severe enough to warrant surgical intervention.
results: Most patients have their arthroscopic surgery as outpatients and are home several hours after the surgery.

overview: Articular cartilage is the smooth, white tissue that covers the ends of bones where they come together to form joints. Healthy cartilage in our joints makes it easier to move. It allows the bones to glide over each other with very little friction. Articular cartilage can be damaged by injury or normal wear and tear. Because cartilage does not heal itself well, doctors have developed surgical techniques to stimulate the growth of new cartilage. Restoring articular cartilage can relieve pain and allow better function. Most important, it can delay or prevent the onset of arthritis.
procedure_description: Many procedures to restore articular cartilage are done arthroscopically. During arthroscopy, your surgeon makes two or three small, puncture incisions around your joint using an arthroscope. Some procedures require the surgeon to have more direct access to the affected area. Longer, open incisions are required. Sometimes it is necessary to address other problems in the joint, such as meniscal or ligament tears, when cartilage surgery is done. In general, recovery from an arthroscopic procedure is quicker and less painful than a traditional, open surgery. Your doctor will discuss the options with you to determine what kind of procedure is right for you.
recovery_time: Several months
rehabilitation: Physical therapy may be prescribed to restore mobility and strengthen the joint and supporting muscles.
success_rate: Varies by procedure and patient condition
when_to_consider_surgery: When cartilage damage is significant and causing pain or functional limitations, especially in younger patients with single lesions.
results: Restoration of cartilage can relieve pain and improve joint function, potentially delaying or preventing arthritis.

surgery_name: Artificial Disk Replacement in the Lumbar Spine
overview: In lumbar artificial disk replacement, worn or damaged disk material between the small bones in the spine (vertebrae) is removed and replaced with a prosthetic, or artificial disk. The goal of the procedure is to relieve back pain while maintaining more normal motion than is allowed with some other procedures, such as spinal fusion (which aims to prevent motion).
causes: Degenerative (arthritic) disks in the lumbar spine
symptoms: Pain not improved with conservative treatment
procedure_description: Most artificial disk replacement surgeries take 2 to 3 hours. Your surgical team will approach your lower back from the front through an incision in your abdomen. During the procedure, your surgeon will remove your problematic disk, then insert an artificial disk implant into the disk space.
recovery_time: 1 to 3 days in the hospital, with early mobilization encouraged
rehabilitation: Basic exercises including routine walking and stretching during the first several weeks after surgery, avoiding activities that cause hyperextension of the back.
success_rate: Improvement of lower back pain and disability in weeks to months after surgery, with success rates ranging from 50 to 90% for lumbar fusion, but artificial disk replacement aims to preserve motion and may have varying outcomes.
when_to_consider_surgery: When low back pain does not improve with conservative treatment and is determined to stem from one or two degenerative disks, as assessed by diagnostic testing and physical exam.
results: Most patients can expect improvement of lower back pain and disability in weeks to months after surgery, but it does not completely eliminate pain.
cost_estimation: Insurance coverage for lumbar disk replacement varies, and many insurance companies do not currently approve lumbar disk replacements.

overview: Awake spinal surgery, also known as intravenous sedation surgery, is a procedure where the patient remains awake during the operation. It can reduce the risks associated with general anesthesia, potentially leading to quicker recovery times and improved results for patients.
procedure_description: In awake spinal surgery, doctors use spinal anesthesia, which numbs the surgical area without putting the patient to sleep. This method is considered safer as it avoids the need for a breathing tube.
risks_and_complications: Not everyone can have this kind of surgery
Anxiety or fear during the procedure
recovery_time: Patients start moving around with help immediately after the procedure and are evaluated for recovery from spinal anesthesia before discharge.

overview: The article provides in-depth information about treatment for anterior cruciate ligament injuries, including surgical techniques and rehabilitation, potential complications, and outcomes.
causes: ACL injuries occur due to sports activities, falls, or accidents that put stress on the knee.
procedure_description: ACL tears are generally replaced by a substitute graft made of tendon, including patellar, hamstring, or quadriceps tendon autograft, or allograft.
recovery_time: 6 to 12 months depending on the patient's progress, strength, and mechanics.
rehabilitation: Physical therapy is crucial, with exercises beginning immediately after surgery. Goals include reducing swelling, maintaining mobility, regaining full range of motion, and strengthening muscles.
success_rate: Most patients are allowed to return to full sports participation within 6 to 12 months, depending on recovery progress.
when_to_consider_surgery: Active adult patients involved in sports or jobs requiring pivoting or turning, or those with significant functional instability should consider surgery.
results: Surgical treatment generally produces better outcomes, especially in cases of combined injuries.

overview: This guide to bone and tissue transplantation is provided by the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) and the American Association of Tissue Banks (AATB).
procedure_description: The procedure involves using a bone or other musculoskeletal tissue from a donor for transplantation.
cost_estimation: Costs for recovering organs and tissues for donation are never passed on to the donor or the donor family.

overview: Spinal fusion is one of the most common surgeries performed in the neck or back. The basic idea is to fuse together painful or unstable bones in the spine so that they heal into a single, solid bone. For bones to fuse or heal together, additional bone is needed. This additional bone is called a bone graft.
procedure_description: The standard technique used in fusion is to take extra bone from one part of the patient's body (harvest) and move (graft) it to another part of the body, such as the spine. This type of bone graft is called an autograft.
risks_and_complications: Risk of fracture at the harvest site

overview: This article provides information on surgery for bunions. Most people with bunions find pain relief with simple treatments to reduce pressure on the big toe, such as wearing wider shoes or using pads in their shoes. However, if these measures do not relieve your symptoms, your doctor may recommend bunion surgery.
procedure_description: Bunion surgery generally involves realigning the bones of the big toe to bring it back to its correct position. The common goals of most bunion surgeries include realigning the metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint at the base of the big toe, relieving pain, and correcting the deformity of the bones that make up the toe and foot.
risks_and_complications: Failure of the bone to fully heal
Stiffness of the big toe joint
recovery_time: Up to 6 months for full recovery, with follow-up visits for up to a year.
rehabilitation: Specific exercises will help restore your foot's strength and range of motion after surgery. Always start these exercises slowly and follow instructions from your doctor or physical therapist regarding repetitions.
when_to_consider_surgery: If your bunion is painful and limits your everyday activities, including walking and wearing reasonable shoes, you may be a candidate for surgery.
results: The majority of patients who undergo bunion surgery experience a reduction of foot pain, along with improvement in the alignment of their big toe.

overview: Cannabidiol, commonly called CBD, is a substance that comes from the plant Cannabis sativa. This article answers some frequently asked questions about the use of CBD to help inform your treatment decisions.
procedure_description: CBD for medical use is available mostly in three forms: cream, gel, or oil. The cream and gel may be rubbed onto the area to be treated. The oil may be put into a drink or on food, rubbed onto a treatment area, or put directly under the tongue.

overview: Cervical artificial disk replacement is a newer procedure that aims to improve neck pain while preserving more normal neck motion than fusion surgery. In cervical disk replacement, worn or damaged disk material between the small bones in the spine (vertebrae) is removed and replaced with an artificial disk.
procedure_description: Most artificial disk replacement surgeries take 2 to 3 hours. You will be given general anesthesia to keep you asleep during the procedure. The surgeon will make an incision in the front of your neck, remove the problematic disk, and insert an artificial disk in its place.
recovery_time: 1 to 2 days in the hospital, with full recovery taking 6 to 12 weeks for strenuous activities.
rehabilitation: Physical therapy may be recommended to aid recovery and improve neck function.
success_rate: Most patients can expect improvement of pain and disability in weeks to months following surgery.
when_to_consider_surgery: Surgery may be considered if you are still having pain after trying conservative treatments.
results: Studies show that disk replacement improves but does not completely eliminate pain.
cost_estimation: Cost may vary based on the facility and insurance coverage.

overview: This article provides information on surgery for cervical radiculopathy. For more general information: Cervical Radiculopathy (Pinched Nerve).
procedure_description: The main goal of surgery is to relieve your symptoms by decompressing, or relieving pressure on, the compressed nerves in your neck. Other goals of surgery include improving neck pain, maintaining stability of the spine, improving alignment of the spine, and preserving range of motion in the neck.
risks_and_complications: The need for additional surgery in the future
Tear of the sac covering the nerves (dural tear)
Life-threatening medical problems, such as heart attack, lung complications, or stroke
recovery_time: Most patients stay in the hospital for 1 night, although some are able to go home the same day. Most patients are able to walk and eat on the first day after surgery. It is normal to have difficulty swallowing solid foods for a few weeks or have some hoarseness following anterior cervical spine surgery.
rehabilitation: Usually, by 4 to 6 weeks, you can gradually begin to do range-of-motion and strengthening exercises. Your doctor may prescribe physical therapy during the recovery period to help you regain full function.
when_to_consider_surgery: When symptoms of cervical radiculopathy continue or worsen despite nonsurgical treatment, your doctor may recommend surgery.
results: Most patients experience favorable outcomes after surgery for cervical radiculopathy. In most cases, they experience relief from their pain and other symptoms and can successfully return to the activities of daily life after a period of recovery.

surgery_name: Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy: Surgical Treatment Options
overview: This article provides information on surgery for cervical spondylotic myelopathy. For more general information: Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy (Spinal Cord Compression)
symptoms: Weakness in the arms or legs
surgical_procedures: Anterior cervical diskectomy and disk replacement
procedure_description: The goal of surgery is to relieve symptoms by decompressing, or relieving pressure on, the spinal cord. This involves removing the pieces of bone or soft tissue (such as a herniated disk or thickened ligament) that may be taking up space in the spinal canal. This relieves pressure by creating more space for the spinal cord.
risks_and_complications: The need for additional surgery in the future
Tear of the sac covering the nerves (dural tear)
Life-threatening medical problems, such as heart attack, lung complications, or stroke
recovery_time: After surgery, you will typically stay in the hospital for 1 or 2 days. This will vary, however, depending on the type of surgery you have had and how many disk levels were involved.
rehabilitation: Usually by 4 to 6 weeks, you can gradually begin to do range-of-motion and strengthening exercises. Your doctor may prescribe physical therapy during the recovery period to help you regain full function.
when_to_consider_surgery: Candidates for surgery include patients who have progressive neurologic changes with signs of severe spinal cord compression or spinal cord swelling. Patients with severe or disabling pain may also be helped with surgery.
results: Outcomes will vary from patient to patient. Typically, with respect to pre-surgical symptoms, one-third of patients improve, one-third stay the same, and one-third continue to worsen over time.

overview: A cortisone shot is a simple in-office procedure in which a steroid, like triamcinolone or methylprednisolone, is injected into a joint in combination with an anesthetic, like lidocaine or bupivacaine. Because the shot includes steroids, it is sometimes called a 'steroid injection.'
procedure_description: The injectable steroid used in a cortisone shot has anti-inflammatory properties. The injectable steroid is deposited on the lining of the joint. As the cells in the lining of the joint interact with the injectable steroid, the cells begin to work with your immune system to reduce inflammation and pain.
risks_and_complications: risk of a flare after a cortisone shot
success_rate: considered an effective treatment option for many patients suffering from joint pain
when_to_consider_surgery: If there is significant pain relief immediately after a cortisone shot, it confirms pain is coming from the joint and can usually be addressed with surgery.
results: A cortisone shot can last for several weeks as the cells in the lining of the joint continue to interact with the injectable steroid.

overview: Cubital tunnel release is a surgical procedure used to treat cubital tunnel syndrome (also known as ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow).
causes: Cubital tunnel syndrome is caused by a pinched ulnar nerve at the elbow.
symptoms: Numbness in the small finger and sometimes the ring finger
Weakness in the muscles of the hand resulting in poor hand function
non_surgical_treatments: Splinting the elbow straight at night
Exercises to help get the nerve moving better behind the elbow
procedure_description: The procedure involves releasing the ulnar nerve by clearing away tissue compressing it and may include transposition of the nerve if necessary.
risks_and_complications: Injuries to nearby structures such as nerves/vessels/tendons
Worsening of the condition after surgery
recovery_time: Patients may return to sedentary jobs a few days after surgery, while those with physically demanding jobs may need 2 to 4 weeks off.
rehabilitation: Patients are advised to avoid injury to the skin over the elbow and manage blood sugar levels if diabetic. Smokers should avoid smoking prior to surgery.
success_rate: Long-term outcomes of cubital tunnel release are good, especially in patients with milder disease over a shorter period of time.
when_to_consider_surgery: Surgery is recommended if nonsurgical treatments are ineffective or if the condition is too severe for nonsurgical treatment to be effective.
results: It can take 12 to 18 months after surgery to see the final results, with some patients experiencing improvement and others not seeing significant changes.

overview: Arthroscopy is a procedure that orthopaedic surgeons use to visualize and treat problems inside a joint. The word arthroscopy comes from two Greek words, "arthro" (joint) and "skopein" (to look). The term literally means "to look within the joint." During elbow arthroscopy, your surgeon inserts a small camera, called an arthroscope, into your elbow joint. The camera displays pictures on a monitor, and your surgeon uses these images to guide miniature surgical instruments.
non_surgical_treatments: Medications or injections that can reduce inflammation
surgical_procedures: Remove loose bodies (loose cartilage and bone fragments)
Release scar tissue and bone spurs to improve range of motion
procedure_description: Your surgeon will first fill the elbow joint with fluid. The fluid helps your surgeon more clearly see the structures of your elbow through the camera on the arthroscope. This lessens the risk of injury to the blood vessels and nerves surrounding your elbow joint. Your surgeon will make several small incisions to introduce the arthroscope and small instruments into the joint. Fluid flows through the arthroscope to keep the view clear and control any bleeding. Images from the arthroscope are projected on the video screen showing your surgeon the inside of your elbow and any problems.
risks_and_complications: Damage to blood vessels or nerves
recovery_time: Recovery from arthroscopy is often faster than recovery from open surgery, but it may still take weeks to months for your elbow joint to completely recover.
rehabilitation: Rehabilitation plays an important role in getting you back to your daily activities. An exercise program will help you regain elbow and forearm motion and strength. Your surgeon will develop a rehabilitation plan based on the surgical procedures you required.
success_rate: Most patients do not experience significant complications from elbow arthroscopy. As with any surgery, however, there are some risks. These are usually minor and treatable and not likely to affect your final outcome.
when_to_consider_surgery: Your doctor may recommend elbow arthroscopy if you have a painful condition that does not respond to nonsurgical treatment.
results: Following your surgeon's guidelines and rehabilitation plan is vital to a successful outcome.

overview: Electrodiagnostic testing measures the speed and degree of electrical activity in your muscles and nerves to help diagnose conditions affecting nerves and muscles.
procedure_description: Electrodiagnostic testing includes two common tests: Electromyography (EMG) and Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS). EMG records electrical activity in muscles, while NCS measures the speed of electrical signals in nerves.
risks_and_complications: Pain and discomfort during EMG needle insertion
Soreness and bruising after needle removal
recovery_time: Typically, results can be obtained soon after the test.
success_rate: Generally accurate in determining injuries to nerves or nerve roots, as well as diseases of nerves and muscles.
when_to_consider_surgery: Surgeons may order electrodiagnostic testing before recommending surgery for conditions like carpal tunnel syndrome, thoracic outlet syndrome, and ulnar nerve entrapment.
results: Results are usually available soon after the test, but may take several weeks for changes to become apparent.

overview: Endoscopic spine surgery is an advanced surgical technique that offers a minimally invasive approach to removing herniated disks in the lower back. In this procedure, the surgeon uses an endoscope (a thin, flexible tube with a camera and light source) to visualize and access the spine through small incisions.
symptoms: Pain in one or both legs
procedure_description: A disk begins to herniate when its jelly-like nucleus pushes against its outer ring due to wear and tear or a sudden injury. This pressure against the outer ring may cause lower back pain. If the pressure continues, the jelly-like nucleus may push all the way through the disk's outer ring or cause the ring to bulge, putting pressure on the spinal cord and nearby nerve roots.
recovery_time: Generally faster compared to open surgery; patients can usually go home the same day or after a short hospital stay.
rehabilitation: Activities may be restricted for a few weeks, and physical therapy may be recommended. Patients are encouraged to gradually resume their normal activities.
success_rate: Promising early results, but long-term outcomes are still being studied.
when_to_consider_surgery: When nonsurgical treatments have failed to relieve painful symptoms or for patients experiencing specific issues such as persistent muscle weakness, difficulty walking, or loss of bladder or bowel control.
results: Patients can usually go home the same day as the procedure or after a short hospital stay, with a faster recovery compared to open surgery.
cost_estimation: More expensive than traditional open surgery due to specialized equipment and expertise required.

overview: Interphalangeal (IP) joint arthrodesis (fusion) is a procedure where a finger joint is prepared and held in a defined position until it heals there. The end result is elimination of motion at that joint by making the two ends of the bone grow (fuse) together.
causes: Trauma to the finger or thumb
procedure_description: During the surgery, the patient is often made sleepy and the surgical site is numbed with medication. The joint is opened so that the surgeon can access the joint surfaces. The joint surfaces are prepared with tools to make them match each other well and expose the healthy/bleeding bone just below the joint. The joint is aligned so the finger is straight from an overhead view and straight or, in some cases, slightly bent from a side view. The joint is then held in this position with the joint surfaces pressed against each other so they can heal together.
risks_and_complications: Injuries to nearby structures such as nerves/vessels/tendons
Hardware issues with the implants used for fixing the fusion
recovery_time: 6 to 12 weeks for the surgery to start to feel beneficial; 9 to 12 months for final results.
rehabilitation: Patients typically are placed in a removable splint and start therapy for gentle motion of the other fingers and the other joints around the fused joint.
success_rate: Most patients are ultimately happy with the surgery. It has excellent rates of pain improvement and functional benefits.
when_to_consider_surgery: Fusion is usually reserved for patients with severe, painful arthritis of the affected joint or chronic joint instability, deformity, or other conditions affecting the function of the finger/thumb/joint.
results: The surgery reliably corrects finger deformities and reduces or eliminates pain.

overview: Spinal fusion is a surgical procedure used to correct problems with the small bones in the spine (vertebrae). It is essentially a welding process. The basic idea is to fuse together the painful vertebrae, so they heal into a single, solid bone.
procedure_description: An interbody fusion is a type of spinal fusion that involves removing the intervertebral disk from the disk space. When the disk space has been cleared out, your surgeon will implant a metal, plastic, or bone spacer between the two adjoining vertebrae. This spacer, or cage, promotes bone healing, helps make the fusion happen, and increases the collapsed intervertebral disk space.
risks_and_complications: Bowel, bladder, or blood vessel injury
recovery_time: Patients typically go home the same day or next day if only one level is fused. If more than one level is fused, most patients stay overnight.
results: Outcomes for lateral lumbar interbody fusion are equivalent to those of traditional surgeries. Because this procedure is performed through a smaller incision, it may minimize muscle damage.

overview: Arthritis pain naturally causes most adults to slow down and limit activity. Not exercising, however, can result in more problems. Recent research shows that over time inactivity actually worsens osteoarthritis pain and puts adults at greater risk for eventual total loss of mobility.
procedure_description: Arthritis management may include a combination of non-surgical and surgical treatments depending on the severity of the condition.
recovery_time: Varies by procedure; typically several weeks to months for full recovery after surgery.
rehabilitation: Physical therapy is often recommended to regain strength and mobility post-surgery.
success_rate: High success rate for joint replacement surgeries, with many patients experiencing significant pain relief and improved function.
when_to_consider_surgery: When non-surgical treatments have failed to relieve symptoms and quality of life is significantly affected.
results: Most patients experience significant pain relief and improved mobility after surgery.
cost_estimation: Costs can vary widely based on the procedure and location, typically ranging from several thousand to tens of thousands of dollars.

surgery_name: Manipulation Under Anesthesia After Total Knee Replacement
overview: Manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) is a non-invasive procedure that helps you regain motion if your total knee replacement becomes stiff.
causes: Incorrect positioning or size of the implant
procedure_description: Before the procedure, you will be given anesthesia (put to sleep) in the operating room. This ensures you will not feel any pain during the procedure. Your doctor will then gently bend and straighten your knee joint, applying gentle force to break up any scar tissue or adhesions causing the tightness. No incision is necessary, though some surgeons will give an injection or a nerve block at the time of the MUA to help with pain control. The procedure typically lasts only a few minutes, and you should be discharged home the same day (outpatient surgery).
recovery_time: Sore and swollen for several days, continue with physical therapy exercises to prevent stiffness from returning.
rehabilitation: Continue with physical therapy exercises to prevent stiffness from returning. Some doctors may prescribe a continuous passive motion machine (CPM).
success_rate: Most patients experience increased knee mobility and reduced pain after the procedure.
when_to_consider_surgery: If stiffness persists after total knee replacement and does not improve with physical therapy.
results: Most patients gain significant motion after their manipulation and are satisfied with their result.

overview: Meniscal transplant surgery is an arthroscopic procedure that replaces a damaged meniscus with donor tissue to relieve knee pain and prevent the progression to osteoarthritis.
procedure_description: The procedure involves replacing the damaged meniscus with donor tissue matched for size. It is performed arthroscopically, usually requiring one or two small incisions.
risks_and_complications: Damage to nearby nerves or blood vessels
recovery_time: 4 to 6 weeks for initial immobilization, with physical therapy beginning once pain and swelling settle down. Full recovery may take 3 to 4 months depending on the patient's job and activity level.
rehabilitation: Physical therapy focusing on pain management, muscle reactivation, and motion, with gradual introduction of strengthening exercises as healing progresses.
success_rate: Between 45% and 79% of transplants succeed within 10 years, with higher success rates for lateral meniscal transplants compared to medial.
when_to_consider_surgery: Younger than 40 to 45 years, physically active, missing a significant portion of the meniscus, persistent activity-related pain, stable ligaments, no or minimal knee osteoarthritis, and not obese.
results: Meniscal transplants can provide significant pain relief and prevent further joint damage for carefully selected patients.

overview: Meniscus repair is an alternative to “trimming” (partial meniscectomy) for some patients with meniscus tears. The procedure helps to restore the cushion between the femur (thighbone) and tibia (shinbone), protecting the cartilage of the knee joint and restoring stability.
procedure_description: Meniscus repair is typically performed for tears in zones that have good blood supply. Repairing the meniscus mends together the torn fibers to aid healing and restore the cushion between the femur (thighbone) and tibia (shinbone).
risks_and_complications: Damage to nerves and blood vessels around the knee
Need for additional surgery after failed repair or reinjury of the meniscus
recovery_time: Patients are expected to return to their normal level of activity at around 6 months, when the meniscus is fully healed.
rehabilitation: Knee range of motion is often gradually progressed during the first 6 weeks. Your surgeon will provide instructions to your physical therapist to appropriately guide your recovery.
success_rate: Return-to-sport rates after meniscus repair are reported to be approximately 91% and 95% after all-inside or inside-out repairs, respectively.
when_to_consider_surgery: Meniscus repair is recommended for active patients with minimal cartilage wear or arthritis, especially those involved in sports or physically demanding activities.
results: The majority of patients do well after surgery and are able to return without functional limitation.

surgery_name: Metastatic Bone Disease: Treatment Options for Specific Areas of Spread
overview: Cancer that begins in an organ, such as the lungs, breast, or prostate, and then spreads to bone is called metastatic bone disease (MBD). Treatment options for MBD often depend on where the bone metastases have developed.
procedure_description: The goals of surgery are stability, functional improvement, and pain relief. Patients not suitable for surgery include those with limited life expectancy, other severe medical problems, small tumors, or tumors that can be treated with radiation alone.
recovery_time: Varies based on the extent of surgery and individual patient factors.
rehabilitation: Rehabilitation may include physical therapy to regain strength and mobility post-surgery.
success_rate: Success rates vary based on the type of surgery and individual patient factors.
when_to_consider_surgery: Surgery is considered when non-surgical management fails, or when there is significant involvement of critical mechanical portions of the skeleton.
results: The results of surgery can lead to improved function and pain relief, but outcomes vary based on individual circumstances.
cost_estimation: Cost estimates vary widely based on the type of treatment and location.

overview: Minimally invasive spine surgery (MISS) accomplishes the same goal as open surgery, but through smaller incisions. It is designed to treat spine problems with less injury to the muscles and other normal structures in the spine.
procedure_description: In these procedures, doctors use specialized instruments to access the spine through small incisions. The surgeon makes a small incision and inserts a tubular retractor through the skin and soft tissues down to the spinal column, creating a tunnel to the small area where the problem exists in the spine.
recovery_time: MISS patients go home the same day or in 1 to 2 days. Most patients having traditional surgery stay in the hospital for 3 to 5 days.
rehabilitation: Your doctor may recommend physical therapy to help you regain strength and speed your recovery.
when_to_consider_surgery: Surgery is usually recommended only when a period of nonsurgical treatment has not relieved the painful symptoms caused by your back problem.

overview: Total hip replacement (also known as total hip arthroplasty) is a common orthopaedic procedure and, as the population ages, it is expected to become even more common. Replacing the hip joint with an implant, or prosthesis, relieves pain and improves mobility, enabling you to resume your normal, everyday activities.
procedure_description: During any total hip replacement surgery, the damaged bone is cut and removed, along with release of some soft tissues surrounding the joint. In minimally invasive surgery, the surgeon makes a smaller surgical incision and cuts or detaches fewer muscles around the hip. Despite this difference, however, both traditional total hip replacement surgery and minimally invasive surgery are technically demanding and have better outcomes if the surgeon and operating team have a lot of experience.
rehabilitation: Physical rehabilitation is a critical component of recovery. Your surgeon or a physical therapist will provide you with specific exercises to help increase your range of motion and restore your strength.
when_to_consider_surgery: Minimally invasive total hip replacement is not suitable for all patients. Your doctor will conduct a comprehensive evaluation and consider several factors before determining whether the procedure is an option for you. In general, candidates for minimal incision procedures are thinner, younger, healthier, and more motivated to participate in the rehabilitation process than patients who undergo the traditional surgery.

overview: Minimally invasive total knee replacement is a variation of traditional knee replacement that uses a shorter incision and a less invasive technique to expose the joint, aiming to reduce post-operative pain and speed recovery.
procedure_description: During any knee replacement, the damaged cartilage and bone from the surface of the knee is removed, along with some soft tissue. The goal of knee replacement is to provide the patient with a pain-free knee that allows for the return to daily activities. The traditional approach uses a long vertical incision, while the minimally invasive technique uses a shorter incision and less cutting of tendons and ligaments.
risks_and_complications: Errors in positioning the prosthetic knee implants
recovery_time: The hospital stay is similar to the length of stay after a traditional total knee replacement, typically 1 to 4 days, with some patients having outpatient surgery.
rehabilitation: Physical therapy is a critical component of recovery, as it is for a traditional total knee replacement. Specific exercises will be provided to help increase range of motion and restore strength.
when_to_consider_surgery: Candidates for minimally invasive total knee replacement are generally thinner, younger, healthier, and more motivated to participate in the rehabilitation process. It may be less suitable for overweight patients or those who have had previous knee surgeries.
results: The short-term benefit of minimally invasive total knee replacement is reported to be less damage to soft tissue, leading to a quicker, less painful recovery and more rapid return to normal activities. Long-term benefits do not differ from traditional total knee replacement.

overview: This article answers frequently asked questions about observation and bracing, as well as physical therapy and alternative therapies such as acupuncture, chiropractic treatment, and yoga.
procedure_description: Surgery is the only treatment that can reduce scoliosis, but it will not usually completely straighten the spine. Bracing can help prevent a curve from getting worse, but it is not expected to improve existing curvature.
risks_and_complications: surgical care is usually recommended for patients with curves greater than 50 degrees
larger curves in children under the age of 10 years are the most likely to progress to needing surgical care
when_to_consider_surgery: If the curve is greater than 50 degrees or if the curve is progressing in a growing child.
